subject: RE: [junit] Testing constructors
msgSnippet: Which generally means ripping the privates out into their own objects, if possible and where appropriate...  By the way, keeping the internal state of the
messageBody:
Which generally means ripping the privates out into their own objects, if
possible and where appropriate... By the way, keeping the internal state of
the object valid at all times is most preferred. If it gets into an invalid
state, the object ought to throw the appropriate exception and be garbage
collected, or recover itself if possible. Allowing objects to float around the
system with invalid states is a recipe for disaster.

-jason

--- "Chappell, Simon P" <simon.chappell@...> wrote:
> The only caveat to this advice is to be certain that you keep the
> internal state of the object valid at all times.
>
> Do you have a lot of code in your constructor because of complex
> internal relationships between the attributes?
>
> If you can move code out of your constructor without risking internal
> validity, then I would certainly recommend it.
>
> Simon

> >IMHO, constructors ought to just construct an object to a sane
> >state, anything
> >else should be external to the constructor. So, initially I
> >would take a lot
> >of the 'functionality' and computation out of the constructor
> >if possible.
> >Once the object is constructed, you should be able to test its
> >state. If not,
> >there's a code smell there. So, I would suggest that you take
> >what you can out
> >of the ctor, construct the object to its known/sane state,
> >then test against
> >that.
> >
> >HTH.
> >-jason
